g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
The most important ways to minimize PVs impact on the environment lie in recycling materials at end
of life and making smart land
cycle analysis (LCA) of resource depletion, land
eutrophication, acidification, ozone, and particulates, among other things
studies show that solar PVs produce far less CO
per unit of electricity than fossi
emissions vary due to the carbon intensity of manufacturing energy and offset electricity
. Concerns about systemic impacts, such as reducing the Earth’s albedo by covering
surfaces with dark panels, have shown to be trivial compared to the mitigation benefits
6.7). Even though GHG LCA estimates s
, recent studies that reflect higher efficiencies and
cycle emissions, including a range of 18
order of magnitude lower than coal
and natural gas and further decarbonization of the energy system
will make them lower still. Thin films and organics produce half the life
wafer PV, mainly because they use less material
promise even lower environmental impacts, especially with improvements to their performance ratios
locations, less carbon intensive manufacturing inputs, and shifting to thin films could reduce future life
Another environmental concern with large PV power plants is the conversion of land to collect solar
. Approximately 2 hectares of land are needed for 1 MW of solar
(Kabir et al. 2018; Perpiña Castillo et al. 2016)
; at 20% efficiency, a square of P
panels of 550 km by 550 km, comprising 0.2% of Earth’s land area, could meet global energy demand.
Land conversion can have local impacts, especially near cities and where land used for solar competes
with alternative uses, such as agriculture. Large ins
tallations can also adversely impact biodiversity
, especially where the above ground vegetation is cleared and soils are
graded. Landscape fragmentation creates barriers to the movement of species. However, a variety of
means have emerged to mitigate land use issues. Substitution among renewables can reduce land
(the use of land for both agriculture and solar production)
. Combining solar and agriculture can also create inco
diversification, reduced drought stress, higher solar output due to radiative cooling, and other benefits
(Elamri et al. 2018; Hassanpour Adeh et al. 2018; Barron
and reservoirs where evaporation can also be reduced
Material demand for PV will likely increase substantially
materials are widely available, have possible substitutes, and c
6.4). The primary materials for PV are silicon, copper, glass, aluminium, and silver, the costliest being
silicon and glass being the most essential by mass, at 70%. None of these materials is considered to be
film cells, such as amorphous silicon, cadmium
telluride and copper indium gallium diselenide (CIGS), use far less material (though they use more
glass), but account for less than 10% of the global solar market. Other thin
perovskites, organic solar cells, or earth
toxic materials such as kesterites, either on
their own, or layered on silicon, could further reduce material use per energy produced. (
After a typical lifetime of 30 years of use, PV
modules can be recycled to prevent environmental
contamination from the toxic materials within them, reusing valuable materials and avoiding waste
